Award.AbstractNarration:
This project is supported by the Electronic and Photonic Materials Program (EPM) and Condensed Matter Physics Program (CMP), both in the Division of Materials Research (DMR).

Nontechnical Description: This research project aims to significantly expand the knowledge on important topics in a nanoscience research field, including nanocarbon materials, transition-metal dichalcogenides in the form of ultrathin layers with thicknesses of only a few atomic layers, and the newly discovered few-layered phosphorus material called phosphorene, which has a novel layered crystal structure and promising electronic, optical, and spectroscopic properties. The research results are published in major scientific journals and presented at national and interternatinal scientific conferences by the principal investigator and participating students and postdoctoral researchers, thereby providing valuable educational experiences for them. In addition, the principal investigator gives colloquia at universities and invited talks in scientific conferences, furthering the nanoscience research field.

Technical Description: The project is on a comprehensive and comparative study of nanocarbons, graphene, transition metal dichalcogenides, and phosphorene. Raman spectroscopy is the main experimental method. The graphene research studies take advantage of the large present knowledge base of the electronic properties of graphene to study new aspects of Raman resonance windows, twist angle phenomena, and electron-phonon interaction phenomena. These studies also can be best carried out in graphene because of its special properties, such as the large isotope effect provided by the carbon 12 and 13 isotopes, which is advantageous for studying electron-phonon interactions quantitatively. Similarly, the role of substrate effects in enhancing Raman spectroscopy signals and symmetry-breaking phenomena produced by external perturbations have been extensively studied in graphene, which now can be used for metrological purposes. In this context, similar physical properties can now be studied productively in few-layer transition metal dichalcogenides and phosphorene individually and on a comparative basis.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The past two decades have witnessed the explosion of two-dimensional materials field since the isolation of mechanically exfoliated monolayer graphene was demonstrated. Nowadays the family of two-dimensional materials has grown, with a bunch of family members, including graphene, boron nitride, transition metal dichalcognides and phosphorene. With strong covalent bonding in an atomic plane and weak interaction between the layers, two-dimensional materials supply an excellent platform to investigate novel physical phenomena. This project focuses on the spectroscopic investigation of layered materials, and is aimed to understand the phonon related physical phenomena in these nano materials as well as develop spectroscopic methods to determine their structures, including layer number, crystalline orientation and phase transition. The scientific efforts supported by this grant primarily focused on transition metal dichalcognides and black phosphorus.

 

Molybdenum disulfide (MoS2) is a prototype of transition metal dichalcognides. The common 2H phase MoS2 is semiconducting while the 1T phase is metallic. During the supported period of this grant, the phase transition of MoS2 from 2H to 1T phase was successfully demonstrated. These two phases display distinctive x-ray and Raman spectroscopic features as well as transport properties. A lateral MoS2 heterostructure with 2H-1T phase junction was designed and a phase-engineered MoS2 Schottky diode was fabricated on flexible substrates. By integrating a MoS2 rectifier with an antenna, the MoS2-enabled rectenna was successfully demonstrated with direct energy harvesting of EM radiation in the Wi-Fi band and lighting up a commercial light-emitting diode (LED) with zero external bias. The flexible rectifier that can operate up to the X-band, covering most of the radio band, including the Wi-Fi channels. The MoS2-based Schottky diode exhibits a cutoff frequency up to 10 GHz, around one order of magnitudes faster than other flexible alternatives, which will be very useful for wireless communication in the flexible and wearable platform.

 

Molybdenum telluride (MoTe2) is another rising star of transition metal dichalcognides, with the higher symmetry semiconducting 2H phase and the lower symmetry metallic 1T’ phase. The latter is an excellent carrier to investigate novel physical properties, such as magnetoresistance and pressure-driven superconductivity. Large-area, uniform and atomically-thin films of 2H and 1T’ MoTe2 have been demonstrated using chemical vapor deposition. Moreover, the syntheses of both 2H and 1T’ phase can be selectively controlled by the amount of precursor Te. Sufficient Te leads to 2H MoTe2 while insufficient Te supply would end up with 1T’ MoTe2. The controlled synthesis lays the foundation for further fundamental investigation and application of MoTe2.   

 

During the past two years of this grant, resonant Raman spectroscopy has been used to investigate the electron-phonon coupling in anisotropic two-dimensional materials, such as black phosphorus. Determined by its puckered structure, black phosphorus shows highly anisotropic electronic structure with anisotropic electron-photon coupling and electron-phonon coupling. The polarized Raman scattering of black phosphorus display abnormal behavior, and it is also dependent on the excitation wavelength, sample thickness and phonon modes. The physical origin of this phenomena in black phosphorus was revealed by measuring the excitation-energy dependent polarized Raman scattering. The intrinsic Raman excitation profiles of Ag phonons in black phosphorus have been obtained, and the abnormal Raman behavior was attributed to the symmetry-dependent electron-phonon coupling. Based on the resonant Raman excitation profiles with the excitation polarizations along armchair and zigzag directions, a reliable Raman method was developed to identify the crystalline orientations of black phosphorus. The anonymous Raman modes, which are forbidden at backscattering configuration, were observed in the Raman spectra of black phosphorus at resonant excitation energy. The resonance window, symmetry and the assignment of these modes were investigated. These investigations give a deep insight into the electron-phonon coupling in black phosphorus, which can be further extended to other two-dimensional anisotropic crystals.

 

This project has provided training opportunities to two graduate students and two postdoctoral researchers in the interdisciplinary research fields of physics and material science. All of them were supported to attend the professional conferences in the related field. These two graduate students have successfully defended their PhD theses. One of the graduate student and one postdoctoral researcher have already found faculty positions, and would continue pursuing their future career in academic field.
